jewish.text: Among those who stand, do not sit; among those who sit, do not stand.
Worries go down better with soup than without.
A bird that you set free may be caught again, but a word that escapes your lips will not return.
A mother understands what a child does not say.
A pessimist, confronted with two bad choices, chooses both.
As he thinks in his heart, so he is.
As you teach, you learn.
Ask about your neighbors, then buy the house.
Do not be wise in words - be wise in deeds.
Don't be sweet, lest you be eaten up; don't be bitter, lest you be spewed out.
Don't live in a town where there are no doctors.
Don't look for more honor than your learning merits.
First mend yourself, and then mend others.
He that can't endure the bad, will not live to see the good.
If charity cost nothing, the world would be full of philanthropists.
If God lived on earth, people would break his windows.
If not for fear, sin would be sweet.
If the rich could hire the poor to die for them, the poor would make a very nice living.
Make sure to be in with your equals if you're going to fall out with your superiors.
Not to have felt pain is not to have been human.
Rejoice not at thine enemy's fall - but don't rush to pick him up either.
What you don't see with your eyes, don't invent with your mouth.
Worries go down better with soup than without.
A bird that you set free may be caught again, but a word that escapes your lips will not return.
A mother understands what a child does not say.
A pessimist, confronted with two bad choices, chooses both.
As he thinks in his heart, so he is.
As you teach, you learn.
Ask about your neighbors, then buy the house.
Do not be wise in words - be wise in deeds.
Don't be sweet, lest you be eaten up; don't be bitter, lest you be spewed out.
Don't live in a town where there are no doctors.
Don't look for more honor than your learning merits.
First mend yourself, and then mend others.
He that can't endure the bad, will not live to see the good.
If charity cost nothing, the world would be full of philanthropists.
If God lived on earth, people would break his windows.
If not for fear, sin would be sweet.
If the rich could hire the poor to die for them, the poor would make a very nice living.
Make sure to be in with your equals if you're going to fall out with your superiors.
Not to have felt pain is not to have been human.
Rejoice not at thine enemy's fall - but don't rush to pick him up either.
What you don't see with your eyes, don't invent with your mouth.
God could not be everywhere and therefore he made mothers.
The charitable give out the door, whilst God puts back through the window
This Too Shall Pass.
It is better that my enemy see good in me than that I see bad in him.
Some of the roads most used lead nowhere.
The innkeeper loves the drunkard, but not for a son-in-law.
... believe not every tale.
Promise little and do much; and receive every man cheerfully.
"Rejoice not at thine enemy's fall"--but don't rush to pick his up, either.
A bird that you set free may be caught again, but a word that escapes your lips will not return.
A cheerful heart is good medicine, but a crushed spirit dries up the bones.
A friend you have to buy; enemies you get for nothing.
A good son-in-law is like the acquisition of a new son; a bad one is like the loss of your daughter.
A half-truth is a whole lie.
A mother understands what a child does not say.
A person worries about the past, distresses about the present, and fears the future.
A pessimist, confronted with two bad choices, chooses both.
A slave shows his true character, not while he is enslaved but when he becomes a master.
Beware of the person who gives you advice according to his own interests.
Charity is the spice of riches.
Commit a sin twice and it will not seem a crime.
Do not ask questions of fairy tales.
Do not be wise in words - be wise in deeds.
Do not make yourself so big, you are not so small.
Do not meet troubles half-way.
Don't approach a goat from the front, a horse from the back, or a fool from any side.
Don't ask questions of fairy tales.
Don't be sweet, lest you be eaten up; don't be bitter, lest you be spewed out.
Whoever enjoys his life is doing the Creator's will.
With money in your pocket, you are wise, and you are handsome, and you sing well too.
Worries go down better with soup than without.
You can't force anyone to love you or lend you money.
You don't need intelligence to have luck, but you do need luck to have intelligence.
Your friend has a friend, and your friend's friend has another friend -- so know when to keep quiet.
Your friend has a friend; don't tell him.
Never trust the man who tells you all his troubles but keeps from you all his joys.
No one is as deaf as the man who will not listen.
One mother achieves more than a hundred teachers.
One of life's greatest mysteries is how the boy who wasn't good enough to marry your daughter can be the father of the smartest grandchild in the world.
Only love gives us the taste of eternity.
People are like grass in the field: some blossom, some wither.
People make plans and God laughs.
Pray that you will never have to bear all that you are able to endure.
Prepare your proof before you argue.
Pride is the mask of one's own faults.
Don't be too sweet lest you be eaten up; don't be too bitter lest you be spewed out.
Don't be too sweet, or else you will be eaten up; but don't be too bitter, or else you will be spitted out.
Don't live in a town where there are no doctors.
Don't look a gift horse in the mouth.
Don't look for more honor than your learning merits.
Don't make a fence more expensive or more important than what it is fencing.
Don't make a mountain out of a molehill.
Don't make a toil of pleasure.
Don't open a shop unless you know how to smile.
Don't pick a wasp out of a cream-jug.
When a father gives to his son, both laugh; when a son gives to his father, both cry.
When a father helps a son, both smile; but when a son must help his father, both cry.
When a habit begins to cost money, it's called a hobby.
When con men meet a legitimately honest man, they are so bewildered that they consider him a greater con man than themselves.
When two divorced people marry, four people get into bed.
When you have no choice, mobilize the spirit of courage.
When you open a door, don't forget to close it. Treat your mouth accordingly.
Where two Jews, three opinions.
Who finds a faithful friend, finds a treasure.
Whoever does not try, does not learn.
Pride joined with many virtues chokes them all.
Pride that dined with vanity supped with poverty.
Sympathy doesn't provide food, but it makes hunger more endurable.
Sympathy is a little medicine to soothe the ache in another's heart.
Teach your tongue to say "I don't know" instead of to make up something.
The good fellow to everyone is a good friend to no one.
The innkeeper loves a drunkard, but not for a son-in-law.
The man who gives little with a smile gives more than the man who gives much with a frown.
The only truly dead are those who have been forgotten.
He that can't endure the bad, will not live to see the good.
He that does not bring up his son to some honest calling and employment, brings him up to be a thief.
He who prays for his neighbor will be heard for himself.
He who puts up with insult invites injury.
Hospitality is one form of worship.
I felt sorry for myself because I had no shoes -- until I met a man who had no feet.
Ideas are something that usually comes like fireman- too late.
If charity cost nothing, the world would be full of philanthropists.
If God lived on earth, people would break his windows.
If not for fear, sin would be sweet.
The person who only accepts friends without faults will never have any real friends.
The poor fool is a man who falls on his back and breaks his nose.
The rich man carries God in his pocket, the poor man in his heart.
The righteous say little and do much.
There is no book that contains absolutely nothing bad, and there is no book that contains absolutely nothing good.
Truth is the safest lie.
What one has, one doesn't want, and what one wants, one doesn't have.
What soap is for the body, tears are for the soul.
What you don't see with your eyes, don't witness with your mouth.
What you give for the cause of charity in health is gold; what you give in sickness is silver; what you give after death is lead.
Don't sell the sun to buy a candle.
Don't trust someone who tells you all of his troubles and keeps you from all of his joys.
Even the most expensive clock still shows sixty minutes in every hour.
First improve yourself, and then judge others.
First learn, and then form opinions.
First mend yourself, and then mend others.
God couldn't be everywhere, so he created mothers.
God gives burdens also shoulders.
God is closest to those with broken hearts.
If the rich could hire someone else to die for them, the poor would make a wonderful living.
If the rich could hire the poor to die for them, the poor would make a very nice living.
If there is bitterness in the heart, sugar in the mouth won't make life sweeter.
If you can't go over, you must go under.
If you don't aspire to great things, you won't attain small things.
If you have money, men think you are wise, handsome, and able to sing like a bird.
If you lie on the ground, you cannot fall.
In a restaurant choose a table near a waiter.
In choosing a friend, go up a step.
It is easier to guard a sack full of fleas than a girl in love.
Against stupidity; God Himself is helpless.
All things grow with time -- except grief.
Among those who stand, do not sit; among those who sit, do not stand. Among those who laugh, do not weep; among those who weep, do not laugh.
Anyone who teases you loves you.
As he thinks in his heart, so he is.
As you do, so will be done to you.
As you teach, you learn.
Ask about your neighbors, then buy the house.
Be sure to send a lazy man for the angel of death.
Be the day weary or be the day long, at last it ringeth to evensong.
Let your ears hear what your mouth says.
Life is the biggest bargain. We get it for nothing.
Locks keep out only the honest.
Loneliness breaks the spirit.
Look for the good, not the evil, in the conduct of members of the family.
Loose tongues are worse than wicked hands.
Make sure to be in with your equals if you're going to fall out with your superiors.
Make sure to send a lazy man for the Angel of Death.
Make sure to send a lazy man the angel of death.
Never trust people who tell you all their troubles but keep from you all their joys.
I ask not for a lighter burden, but for broader shoulders
Love is a sweet dream and marriage is the alarm clock
… And in a place where there are no men, strive to be a man."
He that can’t endure the bad will not live to see the good.
A bachelor should not be a match-maker.
A basic rule of caution: Don’t be overly cautious.
A broken nail cannot be straightened.
jewish.category: jewish proverbs(i.e. it is useless to preach to one completely spoiled)

jewish.text: A dead cow gives no milk.
A defect – the bride is too pretty.
jewish.category: jewish proverbs(usually said when some one is seeking non-existent faults.)

jewish.text: A defendant’s confession is worth a hundred witnesses.
A dream which has not been interpreted is like an unread letter.
A drowning man will grab even for the point of a sword.
A fault-finder complains even that the bride is too pretty.
A fool believes everything he hears.
A full sack stands upright.
A good dream is better than a bad one.
A good name is more valuable than a velvet garment.
A good tree bears good fruit.
A good wife and health are a man’s best wealth.
A healthy person instinctively loves life.
A heavy purse makes a light heart.
A house divided against itself – its future is to be destroyed.
A leader is not necessarily one who knows the way but one who thinks he knows the way.
A little child weighs on your knee, a big one on your heart.
A little fire burns up a great deal of corn.
A man in love is a happy man.
A man is not allowed to eat before he feeds his animal.
A man should stay alive if only out of curiosity.
A man too good for the world is no good for his wife.
A man’s clothes hint at his inner character.
A myrtle standing among reeds still retains the name of myrtle.
A nation’s future lies in its past.
A people’s legends reveal its character more clearly than its acts and events.
A person can understand things deeply through proverbs.
A person cannot create even a tiny worm, but he fashions thousands of idols.
A person is lonely until he finds himself.
A person should not derive pleasure from his modesty.
A person should walk down the middle of the path, and not veer to one side or the other.
A person who lives among the righteous and sins is worse than one who lives among the wicked and sins.
A person who travels knows a great deal.
A quotation at the right moment is like bread to the hungry.
A raven that brings fire to its nest.
A small hole can sink a big ship.
A store is a golden chain.
jewish.category: jewish proverbs(any business, though profitable, keeps its owner tied down.)

jewish.text: A time to keep silent and a time to speak.
A wife is like a defensive wall for her husband.
A wolf loses his hair, but not his nature.
A woman’s voice arouses lust in a man.
A young man has to live, an old man wishes to live.
A young tree bends, an old tree breaks.
A bad partner is worse than rain — the latter makes you go home, while the former makes you go outside.
A deaf man heard a dumb man recount that a blind man saw a lame one run very fast.
A guest and a fish start reeking on the third day.
A man should live at least for curiosity.
According to the camel is the load.
jewish.category: jewish proverbs[great people get bigger burdens.]

jewish.text: Adam was the first lucky man as he had no mother-in-law.
Advice often comes too late when a thing is done.
All people are good from afar.
All things grow with time — except grief.
Always marry for love -but it’s as easy to fall in love with An angry man sleeps alone.
An ill marriage is a spring of ill fortune.
An intelligent mind will search for knowledge.
An intelligent person is like a strong oak: he rides over his misfortune.
Any Jew knows what’s better.
As long as the cow can be milked, it is not brought to the slaughterer.
As men age, their views change.
As you make your bed so will you lie on it.
Ask your enemy for counsel and do the reverse.
At different ages, a person feels differently.
At times you’ll find a people’s outlook in its proverbs.
Attend no auctions if you have no money.
Bad servants ask for advice after the deed is done.
Baseless hate is a serious disease.
Be a pauper rather than a liar.
Be careful not to cause woman to weep, for God counts her tears.
Be exceeding lowly of spirit, for the hope of man is the worm.
Be not sweet, or else you’ll be eaten. Be not bitter, or else you’ll be spat out.
Because of money, the world became ugly.
Being gray of hair means you’re simply old, not wise.
Being too nice can cost a lot. • Too nice can cost a lot of money.
Benevolence does not impoverish all and sundry.
Better a Jew without a beard, than a beard without a Jew.
Better an easy death than a hard life.
Better ask twice than go wrong once.
Better late ripe and bear, than early blossom and blast.
Better to get from God by the spoonful than from Man by the bushel.
Better wit than wealth.
jewish.category: jewish proverbs[wit: intelligence; mind, astute mental soundness and so on, including "clever and apt humour". cf. merriam-webster]

jewish.text: Between bad company and loneliness, the latter is preferable.
Blick auf die Maid, und nicht aufs Kleid.
Cancer–schmancer! – as long as you’re healthy.
Charity and pride have different aims, yet both feed the poor.
Chickens come home to roost.
Choose your companion before (taking) the road.
Choosing between two evils, a pessimist picks both.
Consider the mother, woo the daughter.
Constant dripping eats away at a stone.
Das letzte Hemd soll man versetzen und ein Ojscher (reicher Mann) soll man sein.
Dead men usually tell no tales.
jewish.category: jewish proverbs[saul speaking with the dead samuel]

jewish.text: Death does not knock at the door.
Deeds count; words not so much.
Deliver your words not by numbers but by weight.
Descend a step in choosing your wife.
Dieselbe Sonne bleicht die Leinewand, und bräunt das Gesicht.
Do not abandon us when we grow old.
Do not be wise in words – be wise in deeds.
Do not despise an ignorant man who strives to gain knowledge, or a man of ill repute who strives to redeem his past.
Do not drain the waters of your well while other people may desire them.
Do not grow accustomed to uttering oaths.
Do not limit you children to your own learning, for they were born in a different time.
Do not measure the tail of a live wolf.
Do not place an obstacle before a blind person.
Do not pour out your dirty water ere you have clean water.
Do not put all your cheese into one fritter.
Do not say, "I’ll study when I’m free" – you may never be free. Also: say not, ‘When I have leisure I will study; perchance you may not have leisure.’
Do not side with the majority to do wrong.
Do not swallow poison because you know an antidote.
Don’t be too sweet, or else you will be eaten up; but don’t be too bitter, or else you will be spitted out.
Don’t make a fence more expensive or more important than what it is fencing.
Don’t open a shop unless you know how to smile.
Don’t trust someone who tells you all of his troubles and keeps you from all of his joys.
Don’t approach a goat from the front, a horse from the back, or a fool from any side.
Don’t ask questions of fairy tales.
Don’t bargain when you don’t have any money.
Don’t be choleric and you shall not sin.
jewish.category: jewish proverbs[getting furious may weaken our judgement.]

jewish.text: Don’t be sweet, lest you be eaten up; don’t be bitter, lest you be spewed out.
Don’t be too sweet lest you be eaten up; don’t be too bitter lest you be spewed out.
Don’t enter the forest if you fear leaves.
Don’t follow the majority in the wrong path, because the majority are not always wise.
Don’t gut your fish till you get them.
Don’t live in a town where there are no doctors.
Don’t look a gift horse in the mouth.
Don’t look for more honor than your learning merits.
Don’t make a mountain out of a molehill.
Don’t make a toil of pleasure.
Don’t pick a wasp out of a cream-jug.
Don’t put all your money into one corner.
Don’t sell the sun to buy a candle.
Don’t shame an oldster, for we’ll all be counted among them.
Don’t spit into the well – you might drink from it later.
Don’t throw out an old friend for a new one.
Don’t withhold the good where it is due, if it’s in your power to do it.
Drive your horse with oats – not with a whip.
Dying men speak true.
Each child brings his own blessing into the world, presumably.
Eat to live, at least.
Eat your fill before you get children.Iß dich satt, bevor du Kinder kriegst.
Eggs may be much cleverer than chickens, but they go rotten too quickly.
Even butter and honey make you sick in time.
Even in this world, one can taste the joy of paradise.
Even the weather bureau is sometimes right.
Every man knows that he must die, but no one believes it.
Everyone complains about a lack of money, but none complain about a lack of brains.
Everything should be done within reason.
Experience is the mother of wisdom.
Experience is what we call the accumulation of our mistakes.
Experience is the word people use to call their mistakes.
Faith is not a whole series of axioms but a whole way of life.
Fear a goat in front of you, a horse behind you, and a fool all around.
Fear of the Lord is the beginning of knowledge; fools despise wisdom and morality.
First learn and then teach.
Flattery sits in the parlour when plain dealing is kicked out of doors.
Folly is a joy only to a person lacking in understanding.
Fools love to eat the wrong sorts of sweets.
For the benefit of the flowers, we water the thorns, too.
For the wise, old age is the harvest season.
Frag’ einen Feind um Rat, und mach es umgekehrt.
From a foolish judge, a quick sentence.
From death one cannot hide.
From one who has inherited, not from one for whom men plunder, [accept gifts].
From the black earth there grows the finest grain.
Für die Wahrheit bekommt man Hiebe.
Generations come and go, but controversy lasts.
Gentle speech increases the number of friends.
Gluttony has killed more people than famine has.
God cannot be everywhere at once, that’s why He created mothers.
God couldn’t be everywhere, so he created mothers.
God created man in His own image.
God gave man two ears and one mouth, so listen more and talk less.
God help me rise to my feet; a fall is what I can do myself.
God is a father; luck is a stepfather.
God protect the poor — at least from expensive sins.
Good manners [often] supersede learning.
Growing old, man’s sight worsens, but this allows him to see more.
Habits are at first cobwebs, and at last cables.
Happiness is found in the heart.
Happiness is more than gold.
Happy is she who conducts herself honorably.
Having gone into the city, conform to its laws.
He is at ease who has enough.
He that can’t endure the bad, will not live to see the good.
He that eats till he is sick must fast till he is well.
He that goes for wool may chance to come home shorn.
He that knows nothing, doubts nothing.
He that sows thistles shall reap prickles.
He who changes his location, changes his luck.
He who comes first, grinds first.
He who feels no compassion will become insane
He who flatters you is your enemy – who rebukes you is your friend.
He who has a certain nature will not sell it.
He who knows he is a fool is not a big fool.
He who marries for money earns it.
He who sits at home, does not tear any boots.
Heavy purses and light hearts can sustain much.
He’s got to learn how to shave another’s beard.
How lovely is the sun after rain, and how lovely is laughter after sorrow.
However sweet love may be, you can’t make a stew out of it.
Humour is an important asset: it means understanding and self-criticism. Where humour is absent, you’ll find small-mindedness.
I can chew for you, my child, but you must swallow by yourself.
I felt sorry for myself because I had no shoes, until I met a man who had no feet.
I learned much from my teachers, more from my friends, and the most from my pupils.
Idleness causes much mischief.
If a Jew cannot be a shoemaker, he will dream of being a professor.
If a link is broken, the whole chain breaks. • If one link has broken so has the whole chain.
If a word be worth one shekel, silence is worth two.
If charity cost nothing, the world could be full of philanthropists.
If I am not for myself, who will be?
If it must always be better, it can never be good enough.
If someone is coming to kill you, get up early and kill him first.
If the arrow-maker is killed by his arrow, he is paid out of his own work.
If the Creator wills it, the broom can shoot a bullet.
If the grandmother had a beard she would be a grandfather.
If the house has fallen, woe to the windows.
If the pupil is smart, the teacher gets the credit.
If the wheat of the city be rye-grass, sow of it.
If there is bitterness in the heart, sugar in the mouth won’t make life sweeter.
If there’s a fire at your neighbor’s you, too, are in danger.
If you built up bundles of sins, make bundles of good deeds to offset the former.
If you can’t afford chicken, herring will do.
If you can’t bite, don’t bare your teeth.
If you can’t go over, you must go under.
If you did a good deed, don’t ask for an immediate reward.
If you don’t aspire to great things, you won’t attain small things.
If you ever need a helping hand you’ll find one at the end of your arm.
If you examine carefully enough, everything is tref.
jewish.category: jewish proverbstreif, not kosher. treif is a yiddish word for food that does not conform with jewish religious dietary laws, kashrut.]

jewish.text: If you lack wisdom, what have you got? If you have got wisdom, what do you lack?
If you quarrel with the rabbi, make peace with the bartender.
If you stay at home you won’t wear out your shoes.
If you steal from a thief, you also have a taste of it.
jewish.category: jewish proverbs (just because someone steals, you have no right to rob them.)

jewish.text: If you want to know what God thinks of money, look at the people he gives it to.
If your son-in-law is good, you gained a son. If he is bad, you’ve lost a daughter.
If a problem can be solved with money, then it’s not a problem but a cost.
If charity was worth nothing, everyone would be philanthropists.
If life doesn’t change for the better, wait, and it will change for the worse.
In a large river, large fish swim.
In every generation there is more knowledge of philosophy, and new wisdoms arise – thus new illnesses are added to every generation.
In the hour a man dies, the Law and his good works accompany him.
It is a good tongue that says no ill.
It is a great point of wisdom to find out one’s own folly.
It is best not to live in a city run by scholars.
It is better to eat vegetables and fear no creditors than to eat duck and hide from them.
It is not every question that deserves an answer.
It is not the beard that makes the philosopher.
It is too late to call back yesterday.
It’s better to die of laughter than of fear.
It’s better to talk to a woman than stop living.
It’s easier to be a critic than an author.
It’s good to hope, it’s the waiting that spoils it.
It’s not as good with money, as it is bad without it.
Jealousy has teeth made of iron.
Judge every person with the benefit of the doubt.
Justice shall you pursue.
Keeping good silence is harder than talking good.
Know where you came for, where you are going, and who you are about to give account and reckoning in front of.
Knowledge does not take much space.
Koch einen Bauern süß oder sauer, er bleibt doch alleweil ein Bauer.
Leave the drunkard alone; he will fall by himself.
jewish.category: jewish proverbs[det er eit ord mot å gjere narr av og plage den fulle, eit ord som nok ikkje gjeld nemneverdig for hjelpande hender. tanken som jødar legg i ordtaket er om lag slik: "unngjelding kjem nok i si eiga tid. prøv ikkje å framskynde ho." (jf. cohen no. 198). det er hyppig mange måtar å forstå ordspråk på om vi oppfattar dei figurativt, i overført meining.]

jewish.text: Lend your money and lose your friend.
Life and misery began together.
Life’s not as good with money as it is bad without it.
Love speaks, even when the lips are closed.
Love which depends on some thing, when the thing ceases, the love ceases.
Love work, loath mastery over others, and avoid intimacy with the government. • Love work; and hate lordship; and make not thyself known to the government.
Luck is better than wisdom.
Luck makes you wise, luck makes you wealthy.
Lust [easily] leads to love.
Make no more haste than good speed.
Make room for the new.
Make sure to be in with your equals if you’re going to fall out with your superiors.
Man lives in hope.
Men worry over the loss of their possessions, not over the loss of their years—which never return.
Mind your own business.
Misfortune tell us what fortune is.
Money rules the world.
Money will buy you everything but good sense.
Morality and beauty are essentially the same.
My fathers planted for me, and I planted for my children.
My pen is my harp and my lyre; my library is my garden and my orchard.
My son, do as much good as you can . . . remember, there is no joy in the nether world.
Never be weary of doing good.
Never cry hallo till you are out of the woods.
Never make a promise you cannot keep.
Never mention rope in the house of a man who has been hanged.
Never too late to learn Latin.
Never waste good agony.
Nicht jeder, der am Ehrenplatze sitzt, ist ein vornehmer Herr.
Nine rabbis can’t make a minyan, but ten cobblers, yes.
No individual can be whole without some link to the past.
No one shoe fits every foot.
No person is too old to learn.
No rose without a thorn.
No use crying over spilt milk.
None is as deaf as the man who will not listen.
None should stand up to pray save in sober mood; the pious men of old used to wait an hour before they said their prayer, that they might direct their heart toward God.
Not everyone who is happy today will be happy tomorrow.
Not everyone with a good memory is intelligent.
Not to have felt pain is not to have been human.
Old people often survive the young.
One beggar cannot be at two fairs [at the same time].
One cannot dig a well with a needle.
One has fear in front of a goat, in back of a mule, and on every side of a fool.
One lie begets another.
One match can set fire to a whole city.
One of life’s greatest mysteries is how the boy who wasn’t good enough to marry your daughter can be the father of the smartest grandchild in the world.
One person’s candle furnishes light for many.
One should not send a cat to deliver cream.
One who bears false witness against his friend deserves to be thrown to the dogs.
One who has the reputation of an early riser may safely lie abed till noon.
One’s handwriting delineates his intelligence.
Opinions are scanty, but differences of opinion abound.
Paradise exists everywhere for the true believers.
Parents teach their children to talk; children teach their parents silence.
Partnership is good only with your wife – and there are those who say this too is not certain.
Peace will not rise by force.
Perfection anywhere is very rare.
Play the flute to noblemen (and they find it pleasant; play it) to weavers and they will not accept it. [Fools criticise what the wise admire, adds Cohen. Among Jews, weavers were looked down on.
Poverty and old age often travel together.
Poverty is a wonderful thing. It sticks to a man after all his friends have forsaken him.
Praise a fair day at night.
Pretended holiness is double iniquity.
Prevention is better than cure.
Pride can live in the dungheap.
Pride is the mask of one’s own faults.
Provide for the worst; the best can take care of itself.
Punishment of the sinner should not be seen as revenge.
Real success is success of the soul.
Reflection insures safety, but rashness is followed by regrets.
Regard not the flask, but what is in it; there is a new flask that is full of old (wine), and an old one in which there is not even new (wine).
Rejoice not at thine enemy’s fall – but don’t rush to pick him up either.
Say little and do much.
Say well, or be still.
Schickt man einen Narren einkaufen, dann freuen sich die Krämer.
Scholars expand peace in the world.
Scratching and lending help only for a while.
Sell the Holy Scrolls in the synagogue to give a poor girl a dowry.
Should the castle totter, its name is still castle; should the dunghill be raised, its name is still dunghill.
Should there be a case of hanging in someone’s family record, say not to him, "Hang up this fish".
jewish.category: jewish proverbs[consideration and good judgement can be developed.]

jewish.text: Silence is the fence round wisdom.
Sin crouches at every door.
Slander is worse than idolatry.
Small children stamp on your lap, big ones on your heart.
Some that dance must pay the fiddler.
Some wispered words are heard afar.
Someone else’s worries don’t take away your sleep.
Sometimes a penny is better spent than saved.
Sometimes even the liar will speak the truth.
Sometimes it’s worthwhile for a wise man to play the role of a fool.
Sometimes people admit their mistakes, to mask their crimes.
Strike while the iron is hot.
jewish.description: This old expression comes from the days of blacksmiths (people who work with metal). To shape the metal, the blacksmith would have to beat it with a hammer. Iron is easier to work with when it’s hot. This proverb means you should take advantage of the moment. If an opportunity presents itself to you, take it! Take action because the chance may not come again.

jewish.text: Study today and don’t delay.
Stupid solutions that succeed are still stupid solutions.
Sympathy doesn’t provide food, but it makes hunger more endurable.
Sympathy is a little medicine to soothe the ache in another’s heart.
Teach thy tongue to say, "I do not know.
Teach your tongue to say "I don’t know" instead of to make up something.
Tell nothing to your friend that your enemy does not know.
The beard does not make the philosopher.
The bigger thief is he who steals people’s minds.
The birds of the air despise a miser.
The common soldiers do the fighting, and the officers claim the victory.
The costliest clock can only show sixty minutes in every hour.
The crime itself is the punishment for crime.
The darkest hour of night heralds break of dawn.
The devil lurks behind the cross.
The dog follows you for the crumbs in your pocket.
The egg of today is better than the hen of tomorrow.
The friar preached against stealing and had a goose in his sleeve.
The glory of young men is their strength.
The greatest wisdom is that a person should not be over-wise.
The heart is small and embraces the whole wide world.
The heart of a man may be compared to a sausage; few know exactly what’s inside it.
The man who cannot survive bad times will not see good times.
The man who has confidence in himself gains the confidence of others.
The masses are no asses.
The merchant’s way is first to show you junk, and then the good stuff.
The old lack enthusiasm, the young lack shrewdness.
The pearl is found in mud.
The place does not honour the man – it is the man who gives honour to the place. [It may be a both-end also.]
The rivalry of scholars advances science.
The soldiers fight, and the kings are heroes.
The soul cannot be spat out.
The sun will set without your assistance.
The talk of the child in the street is that of his father or his mother.
The thief on the point of breaking into (a house) calls on God (for help).
The thief who finds no opportunity to steal considers himself an honest man.
The tongue has no bone, yet it crushes.
The truly rich enjoy what they have.
The truth is not always what we want to hear.
The weeping of an heir is laughter under a mask.
The wine belongs to the master, but the waiter receives the thanks.
The wise man conceals his intelligence; the fool displays his foolishness.
The world exists for the sake of kindness.
The world is bound to no man.
The world resembles a collapsing bridge.
The world will not disappear because there are many people, but because there are too many non-people.
There are lots of wise cures for slanderers. One of them is to get and stick to material that brings an accurate, fairly gained picture, and take pains to be precise to that purpose.
There are many academic chairs but few outstanding teachers.
There is no book that has not something bad in it, none that has not something good.
There is no chasm in nature.
There is no place like home.
There is no time like the present.
There is seldom any occasion to light your lamp at noontide.
There’s a time to throw and a time to gather stones.
Through Kamtsa and Bar Kamtsa was the Temple destroyed.
jewish.category: jewish proverbs, [" kamsa and bar kamsa"]

jewish.text: Time and chance happen to everyone.
Time enough to bewail your misfortune when it is here.
To be conscious that you’re ignorant is a great step to knowledge.
Tradition must be a springboard to the future, not an easy chair for resting.
Trees were created for mankind’s companionship.
Truth is a tree of life – you shall eat from it all your life.
Truth is heavy, therefore few care to carry it.
Uphill we always climb with caution, downhill we dash, carefree.
Use your noble vase today; tomorrow it may break..
Verkehrt gefahren ist auch gefahren.
Victuals prepared by many cooks will be neither hot nor cold.
Vom Nichtnehmen ist noch kein Mensch reich geworden.
Vor dem Tod und vor dem Dalles [poverty] kann man sich nicht schützen.
Was nützt es, wenn die Kuh viel Milch gibt, wenn sie nachher den Milchkrug umwirft.
Was nutzt, daß der Bursch Sporen anhat, wenn er nicht reiten kann.
We are too soon old, and too late wise.
We do not even get death free of charge, for it costs us a life.
Weak walls invite the burglar.
Well-known things do not need proof.
Wenn ein Kantor alt wird, bellt er wie ein Hund und frißt wie ein Schwein.
Wenn Gott will, schießt ein Besen.
Wenn man keinen Knoblauch ißt, stinkt man nicht.
What cannot be cured, must be endured.
What is the use of spurs when you cannot ride.
What one has, one doesn’t want, and what one wants, one doesn’t have.
What one wants, one doesn’t have.
What you don’t see with your eyes, don’t invent with your mouth.
What you give for charity while you’re in health is gold; what you give after death is lead.
Whatever has not happened in a thousand years may happen the next moment.
What’s done is done.
When a fool is sent to market, all the merchants are happy.
When a habit begins to cost money, it’s called a hobby.
When a pauper eats a chicken, either he is ill – or the chicken was.
When a thief has no opportunity for stealing he considers himself an honest man.
When an old maiden marries, she becomes a young wife.
When brains are needed, brawn won’t help.
When God is with you, fear not foe!
When he was a puppy, I fed him, and when he became a dog he bit me.
When luck comes, offer him a chair.
When one band is broken, two are broken.
jewish.category: jewish proverbs[a reminder of possible interconnections, as in a loom and a network.]

jewish.text: When one guest brings an uninvited guest, that is improper.
When people have nothing to do, they take up great deeds.
When someone claims an inheritance, he sometimes has to pay for the funeral.
When swindlers meet a genuinely honest man, they’re so astonished they regard him as a greater swindler than themselves.
When the ox falls, they sharpen their knives.
When the ox is down many are the butchers.
When wood is chopped splinters fall.
When you have no choice, mobilise the spirit of courage.
When you open a door, don’t forget to close it. Treat your mouth accordingly.
When your daughter matures, marry her off!
When your enemy falls, don’t rejoice overtly.
When schnapps [‘drink’] goes in, judgment goes out.
Where many go, no grass will grow.
Where there is too much, something is missing.
Wherever I sit, there is the front.
jewish.category: jewish proverbs(usually said by an important person when he declines to sit up front.)

jewish.text: Wherever there is a secret, smell if something is wrong.
Whether a person be Jew or Gentile . . . according to his acts does the Divine Spirit rest upon him.
While the fire is burning, slice your pumpkin and roast it.
jewish.category: jewish proverbs["strike while the iron is hot" has the same main meaning.]

jewish.text: Who doesn’t have children brings them up best.
Who has eaten of the pot knows the taste of the broth. [About knowing things from one’s own experience.
Who seeks more than he needs hinders himself from enjoying what he has.
Who sits on the ground fears no fall.
Who slanders others for what they are innocent of will be damned for his own guilt.
Who spends before he thrives, will beg before he thinks.
Whoever enjoys his life is doing the Creator’s will.
Whoever is crying for the past is praying in vain.
Whoever teaches his son teaches not only his son but also his son’s son, and so on to the end of generations.
Wie du einen ansiehst, so sieht er aus.
Wie kommt die Katz übers Wasser? "Mit nasse Fuß."
Wisdom by itself does not pay for groceries.
Wisdom goes not always by years.
Wisdom is a very great pedigree.
Wisdom is more precious than jewels.
With money in your pocket, you are wise, handsome, and you sing well too. [i.e. – you are fawned on]
With much wealth comes many worries.
jewish.category: jewish proverbs[- and easily, unless you are smart at handling such things and what each brings].

jewish.text: With wisdom alone you cannot go to market.
Without [sound] family life, no nation can be built.
Woe to him who is hated by all, or to him who is loved by all.
Words should be weighed, and not only counted.
Words should be weighed, not counted.
Work [has the capacity to] make life sweet.
Ye wise, be guarded in your words.
You can’t force anyone to love you or lend you money.
You don’t put the cat in charge of the cream.
You don’t need intelligence to have luck, but you do need luck to have intelligence.
Your enemy’s enemy is your friend.
Your friend also has a friend.
jewish.category: jewish proverbs(so be wary of telling your secrets even to your friends.)

jewish.text: Your friend has a friend, and your friend’s friend has another friend — so know when to keep quiet.
Your friend has a friend; don’t tell him.
Crime and bad lives are the measure of a State’s failure, all crime in the end is the crime of the Commit a sin twice and it will not seem a crime.
Ideas are something that usually comes like fireman– too late.
I ask not for a lighter burden, but for broader shoulders.
Among those who laugh, do not weep; among those who weep, do not laugh.
Do not be wise in words — be wise in deeds.
Better an honest smack in the face than a false kiss.
What you don’t see with your eyes, don’t witness with your mouth.
Never kiss an ugly girl; she will tell everyone.
I felt sorry for myself because I had no shoes — until I met a man who had no feet.
He who has no hand cannot clench his fist.
What the daughter does, the mother did.
God could not be everywhere, so he created mothers.
Don’t make toil of pleasure.
Taxes grow without rain.
Poverty is no shame — but is no great honor either.
Because you have drowned others, you were drowned, and in the end, those who drowned you will be drowned.
You only hear three voices in this world: the babbling of the stream, Jewish law, and money.
You can’t force anyone to love you or to lend you money.
The worst life is better than the best death.
If the rich could hire someone else to die for them, the poor would make a wonderful living. .
He that does not bring up his son to some honest calling and employment brings him up to be a thief.
Love is a sweet dream, and marriage is the alarm clock.
